question.title: Translate public id string into public id urn using rfc 3151
question.body:
RFC 3151 provides a way to encode general public ids to URNs. For example, -//OASIS//DTD DocBook XML V4.1.2//EN becomes urn:publicid:-:OASIS:DTD+DocBook+XML+V4.1.2:EN.

Is there a facility in the Java standard library that allows to translate such strings? Something like Translator.toUrn("-//OASIS//DTD DocBook XML V4.1.2//EN")) that would yield the URI urn:publicid:-:OASIS:DTD+DocBook+XML+V4.1.2:EN?

Otherwise, can I reduce implementation complexity of the RFC algorithm by reusing some already existing logic? For example, it feels like encoding ; to %3B and the like should already be implemented somewhere.

answers.body: Worth mentioning that this URL-friendly alternative syntax is also part of ISO 8879 (SGML) Annex K (ISO 8879:1986/Cor 2:1999) aka The WebSGML Additions defining XML 1.0 as a profile of SGML and adding features (eg. XML-style empty elements) but mostly means to express restrictions introduced with XML (eg. requirement for a document to be fully-tagged) (see sgmljs - SGML Syntax Reference for details and the official SGML declaration for XML 1.0 up to 4th ed. at the end). Hence, even though URN YES is not part of the SGML declaration for XML, you may have luck finding support for URN syntax in old Java XML parsers, but I doubt it. As mentioned in the linked SGML syntax reference, sgmljs does support URN syntax for formal public identifiers; it's not a very complex task to implement it on top of regular public identifier and generic URL parsers/encoders.

question_comments.body: @MichaelKay your comment is the most accurate answer to my question so far. If you make it an answer I will be able to validate it. (imhotapâ€™s answer is very useful as well but not really an answer to my question about Java.)

The metadata for the RFC says "This RFC is labeled as "Legacy"; it was published before a formal source was recorded. This RFC is not endorsed by the IETF and has no formal standing in the IETF standards process." My guess is that it's defunct and has never been implemented anywhere.
